document.masterDocTitle: The spiders of Québec: update, additions and corrections

Remark.—
Emblyna chitina
is morphologically similar to
Emblyna peragrata
and the two species have been confused in the past. Recent examination of representatives of both species by D.J. Buckle (pers. comm.) shed light on the problem. We have studied the specimens curated at the CNC and our own records (given above) and confirm his findings. This allows us to clarify the distribution of the two species.
Emblyna chitina
is a widespread boreal species, found from Alaska, British Columbia to Québec, while
E. peragrata
is restricted to the West Coast of British Columbia .
Chamberlin & Gertsch ( 1958 )
list "one female, probably this species" from Rousseau Bay, Tchapahipane Is., Québec in the list of localities given for
E. peragrata
. Fortunately, this record was overlooked by all authors who treated the spiders of Québec as it now appears erroneous. Females, as all female of the
Emblyna / Dictyna
complex, are especially difficult to distinguish and it is best to consider the record of
E. peragrata
from Québec by
Chamberlin & Gertsch ( 1958 )
as a mis­identification of
E. chitina
.
Renault ( 1968 )
recorded and illustrated a species from New Brunswick under the name
Dictyna
near
peragrata .
Most likely, he was also referring to
E. chitina
.
